reviews.advice: Allow for classes to be cancelled on major holidays, a good portion of the classes are missing a fair number of kids. It's a waste to teach only two kids or only talking to two parents.
reviews.cons: The cons also involve the children I work with. Sometimes you'll get the children who need all your attention, won't focus, will hit other children or yourself, or destroy the classroom around them. This job needs a lot of patience. You'll wonder if some of the students need their hearing checked and you'll wonder where you put the headache medication. There is also the language barrier to contend with. You'll be working with a lot of local staff who don't necessarily speak a lot of English and you'll either need a local teacher to translate or you will have to talk very slowly and use small words. Even then, communication gets a little weird. It's also very much a business and there is heavy emphasis on making sales and selling classes. Sometimes it feels like we are making the children into a product for their parents to buy.
reviews.pros: This job is full of pros, there is a great teacher community where teachers get together to do activities and events, majority of the kids and teens I teach are lovely and I enjoy the center I am at. The experience that I have gained from EF is certainly priceless in the people I have met and the random events that have happened in my life. Many of my pros revolve around the kids I teach. I love interacting with them and teaching them a couple more words, while they teach me some stuff. It is such an awesome feeling when one of the kids who was struggling is finally able to speak a full sentence flawlessly or when everyone is having such a good time that the lesson goes flawlessly. It's amazing how much of the local language you pick up as a kids teacher too. With kids using simpler sentences and more exaggerated body language than their adult counterparts that understanding what they need or want is sometimes very easy.
reviews.summary: Kids and Teens are a good way to start

reviews.advice: Don't hang on to someone who's toxic. Bite the bullet and let them go early!

The amount of paperwork---all of it online in the EF system---is tiresome, although I guess it's rooted in some sound 21'st century management philosophy.
reviews.pros: This was my first full-time work at a private training center in China. There was a real cirriculum based on decent pedagogical principles. Pay is good for a Tier 3 city. Management fairly competent.

reviews.advice: Let teachers teach. Stop the constant pressure to upsell to your existing students and get them to promote the company to their friends. Treating students as revenue streams rather than learners is entirely antithetical to the company's professed values.
reviews.cons:
There are a few, but I'll list just some:

* Classes are scheduled on a cycle, so after a while, they become repetitive. There is little incentive or reward for innovation in teaching, and the workload is fairly heavy, so sometimes you end up clicking through powerpoint presentations rather than actually pro-actively teaching.

* The company is overly focused on sales, which sometimes leads to bad outcomes for students and management don't really care about the quality of education that is offered as long as students don't ask for refunds (although this is endemic in the training centre industry in China). For all that EF relies on its corporate image as a company that treats education seriously, in my experience, education is very much a secondary consideration to student satisfaction and successful NPS ratings.

* The corporate culture ground me down a little. Your mileage may vary, but for me the enthusiasm with which central initiatives have to be met, and the constant pressure to be a happy, smiling, 'EF person' had vaguely Stalinist undertones. Toning this down (as well as EF's garish pink colour palette) and encouraging innovative thinking on the ground might improve both morale and performance.

* If you join the company as a teacher, there is little in the way of meaningful career progression available. Once you are teaching 'satisfactory' lessons, the incentive to progress isn't really there. The career progression opportunities which are available are limited, and inconsistently awarded, as management seems to operate on a patrimonial basis, which sometimes results in the wrong people being promoted.

* Pay is low compared to equivalent jobs in training centres, although it is worth noting that International Teachers still receive a very comfortable salary by local standards. 

* Holidays for teachers are good compared to many Chinese companies: new employees end up with 21 days a year. However, if your goal is to travel in China, you may be disappointed. Additionally, teachers are required to be in the office for 40 hours a week and most of the time they will teach until 8 or 9pm. If your goal is to see China or learn the language, you will get an easier schedule and longer holidays working in a university, although it is worth noting that EF pays slightly higher than the average salary teaching in a university in China.

Broadly speaking, I would say that if you're a new teacher interested in moving to China (and potentially a career in China after EF), then EF is worth considering as they do provide more support than many of their competitors. If, however, you're an experienced teacher, passionate about education or interested in immersing yourself in Chinese culture, you can probably find something else more suitable.
reviews.pros:
In my experience as an International Teacher in China, the main pros of EF is the support you receive from the company to relocate to China and learn how to teach English to a reasonable level. For someone new to teaching, EF provides everything you need so that you won't make a fool of yourself. 

Unlike some companies in the industry, EF is unlikely to screw you over too badly: they pay you on time, and you won't be working without a visa.
reviews.summary: A route into teaching in China, but not a career

reviews.advice: Increase salary. Add compensation for extra hours. A specially trained team should be put in place and hired for the emergency weekend line. Increase the payment to the families that care for students. Actually stick to the company values and not just forget about them. Be open to new ideas and improvement. Improve your training of staff, specially in the Sales departments.
reviews.cons:
There is an enormous difference on the professional experience that employees working for the corporation have vs the employees in the schools. If you are part of the corporation you will find many pros, and not so many cons. 
But working for a school I found:
Excessive dependency on the "extra mile". Employees are highly underpaid, extra hours (you will have to do many)  are not compensated. When you are not able to achieve this you will be made feel guilty by managers for not "being a team player" or not "going the extra mile". When you actually do, you will not be recognized for this.
You are put in charge every 3 months or so of an emergency line that works 24/7 during the weekends without extra pay. Training for this is extremely limited and cases may vary from small issues that are easily solved to real emergencies that are incredibly stressful and not suitable to be coped by every employee. 
Too many responsibilities to handle by unprepared staff. The company is highly stingy and hires many interns (unpaid).
Despite the company having strict rules about expected student behavior, it all seems to be forgotten for the sake of money.
Lawsuit threats happen on a daily basis, and with reason. Sales departments around the globe are focused on selling an incredible amount of courses in such a short amount of time to the point of being dishonest with the customer and simply not following the right procedures, affecting everyone along the way: students and employees.
The turnover of staff is incredibly quick. Most employees around me didn't last more than 2 years. Everyone was quite unhappy and frustrated professionally. 
The company has many great families that host the students, but they are constantly mistreated with a terrible pay and no compensation whatsoever when mistakes happen. The company relies on the families' goodwill, without actually caring for them. It is quite a challenge for the accommodation team that has to deal with disappointed families on a daily basis.
Many team building activities do happen, but most of them end up becoming an alcoholic fest. If you are an introvert or socially anxious person this will not be an environment for you. Not going to the activities is of course always an option, but you will later be judged for it as "not a sociable employee" or "doesn't get along with fellow coworkers"
Many things have to be improved.

reviews.cons:
Only a couple:

- Even though I have no plans for leaving any time soon, some of my good friends who have left have said that the company can make things difficult (lack of release letters, stuff with certificates etc.), probably because they don't want to lose their talent to elsewhere. My advice to them would be that even though it can be difficult losing a valued teacher, to try and deal with it with grace. Maybe some people have important personal reasons why they must leave, I'm sure they don't just dislike EF. Let's improve our reputation by being as supportive as we can :)

- Sometimes teachers can be asked to do things that take planning time at very short notice. It's understandable that requests can be made, but I'd recommend giving teachers just a bit more time to try and organise things (maybe give them fewer classes in those 24 hours or something).

- The procedure for claiming back expenses can be a bit laborious, but maybe this is due to local laws and stuff, and thus perhaps it can't be helped.

- Local Chinese staff in other departments sometimes are 'first on the chopping block' in times of trouble. I understand that the company really values its teachers, but it just seemed a bit sad to see this in COVID times for instance.
reviews.pros:
+ The colleagues you meet are almost always lovely people with a real passion for their job, and truly care about the students they teach. I've worked in a number of companies, both in my home country and in China, and I must say, they're in general the friendliest (and intelligent too) bunch I've come across. It's a real pleasure being able to work alongside talented individuals like these.
+ Wonderful, caring managers who care about their employees (everywhere I've worked, anyway).
+ Ample time for preparing classes, and for newer teachers, there are fewer classes as planning them is more difficult when you begin (I think this is very well thought out).
+ Very clear terms and conditions in detailed contracts from the beginning - a very professional company (I've worked for others in China that are nowhere near this).
+ Proper visas - they won't screw you around.
+ The CEO and the very top team are very business-minded, and have a clear vision for the company. I like that in challenging times, they don't just 'shut up shop', and instead, try and make things work through adjustments.
+ The training is second to none. I've recently been on a fabulous Cert TESOL course to gain more experience - the tutors were excellent, and despite having 4-5 years at EF, I've learned even more from it. It's just a shame some of those great people are leaving soon.
+ You're always listened to (at least, whenever there is anything truly serious happening).
reviews.summary: Wonderful, professional company with amazing people.
